newsitem.title: CROATIA: Croatia says VAT goes ahead in 1998.
newsitem.headline: Croatia says VAT goes ahead in 1998.

text.p: Croatia will launch a delayed value-added tax (VAT) next year to complete the fiscal reform, Finance Minister Bozo Prka said on Thursday.
"VAT goes ahead definitely," Prka told Reuters in an interview.
"There was never any dilemma if VAT should be implemented or not. It is vital for harmonising our fiscal system with that in most parts of Europe," he said.
VAT was due to be introduced at a single rate of 22 percent from January this year to replace the turnover tax, currently around 26 percent.
But its launch was put off under pressure from various groups, warning against a price increase of basic products such as foodstuffs that are now taxed at a lower rate.
A shortfall in tax revenue in the election year was another worry for the ruling HDZ party that the Croatian opposition may have used against it.
The government is even now weighing different macroeconomic considerations against social concerns, Prka said.
Various proposals including lower tax on tourist services and a zero rate on baby food have also been put forward since VAT was scrapped.
"I do not exclude the possibility of two rates, but no more," the minister said. "The second rate would only apply to a very narrow group of products."
Prka said one of the aims of VAT was to ease the fiscal burden, and the government hoped it would also have a slight deflationary effect.
But its introduction was seen as initially raising at least some prices.
"There may be a one-off increase, but the balloon will slowly deflate. We do not want to use VAT to raise more tax revenue or increase the (fiscal) burden."
VAT should simplify things and eliminate a cascading effect that the current multiple taxation has on all except simplest of products, he added.
This is estimated to make sophisticated products some three percent more expensive through taxes on raw material, power and other costs piled up in various stages of production.
VAT's introduction is also designed to boost Croatia's competitiveness abroad, partly through tax refunds, Prka said.

"VAT will reduce the burden, particularly for export businesses. It should significantly cut down the prices of companies such as (electrical firm) Koncar, of the machinery and shipbuilding," he said. -- Zagreb Newsroom, 385-1-4557075
